elements.content: Control over the assembly of thorium-based polyoxo-clusters remains a great challenge because of their quick olation and oxolation reactions. Here, we report the synthesis and isolation of two pure phase thorium polyoxo-cluster-based metal–organic frameworks (Th-MOFs), Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011. Crystal structures of these Th-MOFs reveal two distinct 8-connected polyoxo-clusters: a hexanuclear cluster [Th6(μ3-O)4(OH)4(H2O)6(HCOO)4] was observed in Th-NU-1008 and a tetranuclear cluster [Th4(μ3-O)2(OH)4(DMF)2(H2O)4] in Th-NU-1011 which has never been reported before among thorium species. In both Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, the tetratopic linker, 1,4-dibromo-2,3,5,6-tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl) benzene, joins the clusters together, forming two three-periodic networks, each with csq topology. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas calculated from the Ar isotherms are approximately 800 and 700 m2 g–1 for Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, respectively. Because the linkers are oriented orthogonal to each other in the two respective MOFs, a 32 Å hexagonal channel is observed in Th-NU-1008 while a 15 Å channel is observed in Th-NU-1011. This work opens a new avenue to construct unexplored Th-MOF materials with targeted polyoxo-cluster structures.
elements.clean_text: Control over the assembly of thorium-based polyoxo-clusters remains a great challenge because of their quick olation and oxolation reactions. Here, we report the synthesis and isolation of two pure phase thorium polyoxo-cluster-based metal-organic frameworks (Th-MOFs), Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011. Crystal structures of these Th-MOFs reveal two distinct 8-connected polyoxo-clusters: a hexanuclear cluster [Th6(μ3-O)4(OH)4(H2O)6(HCOO)4] was observed in Th-NU-1008 and a tetranuclear cluster [Th4(μ3-O)2(OH)4(DMF)2(H2O)4] in Th-NU-1011 which  has never been reported before among thorium species. In both Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, the tetratopic linker, 1,4-dibromo-2,3,5,6-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl) benzene, joins the clusters together, forming two three-periodic networks, each with csq topology. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas calculated from the Ar isotherms are approximately 800 and 700 m2 g-1 for Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, respectively. Because the linkers are oriented orthogonal to each other in the two respective MOFs, a 32 Å hexagonal channel is observed in Th-NU-1008 while a 15 Å channel is observed in Th-NU-1011. This work opens a new avenue to construct unexplored Th-MOF materials with targeted polyoxo-cluster structures.

elements.content: Recently, thorium-based fuels have received considerable attention due to their high energy output per weight and decreased waste production compared to uranium. However, the processing and disposal of radioactive, thorium-based nuclear waste requires a comprehensive understanding of the chemical and physical properties of thorium species at different conditions. Unfortunately, isolating and characterizing pure thorium species can prove difficult due to their quick hydrolysis reactions, which lead to the formation of various thorium polyoxo-clusters in a mixture form. Spectroscopic techniques indicate that a large variety of thorium polyoxo-clusters, including dimers, trimers, tetramers, hexamers, octamers, and decamers, coexist in aqueous solution at a given pH. Nevertheless, isolation and characterization of a pure phase of thorium clusters remains a challenge. One effective strategy to control the assembly of thorium clusters is to add capping ligands or counterions. Several discrete or polymeric thorium clusters have been successfully obtained using carboxylates, phosphonates, sulfates, selenates, iodates, and other capping groups.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, thorium-based fuels have received considerable attention due to their high energy output per weight and decreased waste production compared to uranium. However, the processing and disposal of radioactive, thorium-based nuclear waste requires a comprehensive understanding of the chemical and physical properties of thorium species at different conditions. Unfortunately, isolating and characterizing pure thorium species can prove difficult due to their quick hydrolysis reactions, which lead to the formation of various thorium polyoxo-clusters in a mixture form. Spectroscopic techniques indicate that a large variety of thorium polyoxo-clusters, including dimers, trimers, tetramers, hexamers, octamers, and decamers, coexist in aqueous solution at a given pH. Nevertheless, isolation and characterization of a pure phase of thorium clusters remains a challenge. One effective strategy to control the assembly of thorium clusters is to add capping ligands or counterions. Several discrete or polymeric thorium clusters have been successfully obtained using carboxylates, phosphonates, sulfates, selenates, iodates, and other capping groups.

elements.content: Based on a similar concept, unstable actinide species have been fixed into periodic metal–organic framework (MOF) matrices, generating materials which have become an emerging research focus in actinide chemistry. While many uranyl-based MOFs have been reported with diverse topologies, high porosity, and novel functionalities, only a few thorium-based metal–organic frameworks (Th-MOFs) have been successfully isolated. Though various secondary building units, including thorium-oxo chains, mono-, tri-, or hexa-nuclear thorium clusters, have been reported in Th-MOFs under different synthetic conditions, a systematic study about the formation of these building units is missing. Thus, it is highly desirable to develop a synthetic strategy to precisely control the assembly of thorium-based clusters as secondary building units before we can rationally design and construct Th-MOFs with predictable topologies and functionalities.
elements.clean_text: Based on a similar concept, unstable actinide species have been fixed into periodic metal-organic framework (MOF) matrices, generating materials which have become an emerging research focus in actinide chemistry. While many uranyl-based MOFs have been reported with diverse topologies, high porosity, and novel functionalities, only a few thorium-based metal-organic frameworks (Th-MOFs) have been successfully isolated. Though various secondary building units, including thorium-oxo chains, mono-, tri-, or hexa-nuclear thorium clusters, have been reported in Th-MOFs under different synthetic conditions, a systematic study about the formation of these building units is missing. Thus, it is highly desirable to develop a synthetic strategy to precisely control the assembly of thorium-based clusters as secondary building units before we can rationally design and construct Th-MOFs with predictable topologies and functionalities.

elements.content: Generally, the hydrolysis rate of thorium polyoxo-clusters is dependent on pH, concentration of water, and temperature. Previously, Loiseau et al. reported that Th cluster building units can be controlled by tuning the DMF/water ratio; using this synthetic strategy, they generated three different Th-MOFs, each with a unique cluster type (mono-, hexa-, or chain-like nodes) through solvothermal synthesis. Inspired by this work, we hypothesize that the thorium polyoxo-cluster hydrolysis rate during Th-MOF formation can be controlled by the concentration of water and importantly the nature of modulator. To test our hypothesis, we chose 1,4-dibromo-2,3,5,6-tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl) benzene (TCPB-Br2) as a linker to form csq topology Th-MOFs. Previously, we have proven that TCPB-Br2 can assemble with Zr6O8 clusters to construct a csq topology MOF, NU-1008. Thus, it is expected that a csq topology Th-MOF could form if Th6O8 clusters are formed in situ and capped by TCPB-Br2. Interestingly, TCPB-Br has a rectangular shape with two dimensions (14 × 9 Å) (a). Thus, we were curious to observe which way it would align by itself in the MOF. Here, we report the synthesis and characterization of two Th-MOFs: Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011. Although they are constructed from the same thorium salt and organic tetratopic linker, TCPB-Br2, the resulting Th-MOFs are composed of different thorium polyoxo-clusters; while Th-NU-1008 exhibits a hexanuclear polyoxo-cluster [Th6(μ3-O)4(OH)4(H2O)6(HCOO)4], a tetranuclear polyoxo-cluster [Th4(μ3-O)2(OH)4(H2O)4(DMF)2] is observed in Th-NU-1011, the first reported of its kind. Additionally, pure and mixed phases of the two Th-MOFs can be obtained by systematically controlling the amount of water and modulators, indicating a plausible strategy to construct new and pure Th-MOFs with polyoxo-cluster building units.
elements.clean_text: Generally, the hydrolysis rate of thorium polyoxo-clusters is dependent on pH, concentration of water, and temperature. Previously, Loiseau et al. reported that Th cluster building units can be controlled by tuning the DMF/water ratio; using this synthetic strategy, they generated three different Th-MOFs, each with a unique cluster type (mono-, hexa-, or chain-like nodes) through solvothermal synthesis. Inspired by this work, we hypothesize that the thorium polyoxo-cluster hydrolysis rate during Th-MOF formation can be controlled by the concentration of water and importantly the nature of modulator. To test our hypothesis, we chose 1,4-dibromo-2,3,5,6-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl) benzene (TCPB-Br2) as a linker to form csq topology Th-MOFs. Previously, we have proven that TCPB-Br2 can assemble with Zr6O8 clusters to construct a csq topology MOF, NU-1008. Thus, it is expected that a csq topology Th-MOF could form if Th6O8 clusters are formed in situ and capped by TCPB-Br2. Interestingly, TCPB-Br has a rectangular shape with two dimensions (14 × 9 Å) (a). Thus, we were curious to observe which way it would align by itself in the MOF. Here, we report the synthesis and characterization of two Th-MOFs: Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011. Although they are constructed from the same thorium salt and organic tetratopic linker, TCPB-Br2, the resulting Th-MOFs are composed of different thorium polyoxo-clusters; while Th-NU-1008 exhibits a hexanuclear polyoxo-cluster [Th6(μ3-O)4(OH)4(H2O)6(HCOO)4], a tetranuclear polyoxo-cluster [Th4(μ3-O)2(OH)4(H2O)4(DMF)2] is observed in Th-NU-1011, the first reported of its kind. Additionally, pure and mixed phases of the two Th-MOFs can be obtained by systematically controlling the amount of water and modulators, indicating a plausible strategy to construct new and pure Th-MOFs with polyoxo-cluster building units.

elements.content: (a) Dimensions of TCPB-Br2 linker. (b) Hexanuclear polyoxo-cluster in Th-NU-1008. (c) Tetranuclear polyoxo-cluster in Th-NU-1011 with the rhombic shape highlighted in purple. Packing diagram of (d) Th-NU-1008 and (e) Th-NU-1011 along the c axis showing hexagonal and triangular channels. Side view of linker orientations (marked in black dashed rectangles) in (f) Th-NU-1008 and (g) Th-NU-1011 along a axis. Th is represented in cyan, O in red, C in gray, and N in blue.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Dimensions of TCPB-Br2 linker. (b) Hexanuclear polyoxo-cluster in Th-NU-1008. (c) Tetranuclear polyoxo-cluster in Th-NU-1011 with the rhombic shape highlighted in purple. Packing diagram of (d) Th-NU-1008 and (e) Th-NU-1011 along the c axis showing hexagonal and triangular channels. Side view of linker orientations (marked in black dashed rectangles) in (f) Th-NU-1008 and (g) Th-NU-1011 along a axis. Th is represented in cyan, O in red, C in gray, and N in blue.

elements.content: After adding a suitable amount of water and benzoic acid to the mixture of thorium nitrate and TCPB-Br2 in DMF and heating at 120 °C, pale-yellow rodlike crystals were obtained (). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies of these crystals revealed two different crystal structures, namely, Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011. Both materials crystallized in the hexagonal space group with P6/mmm symmetry for Th-NU-1008 and P6/mcc symmetry for Th-NU-1011 (). However, Th-NU-1008 was observed to display a hexanuclear polyoxo-cluster [Th6(μ3-O)4(OH)4(H2O)6(HCOO)4] while Th-NU-1011 possessed a tetranuclear polyoxo-cluster [Th4(μ3-O)2(OH)4(H2O)4(DMF)2]. The hexanuclear polyoxo-cluster (b) in Th-NU-1008 was similar to those previously reported in discrete hexanuclear thorium polyoxo-clusters and thorium UiO-66. Most reported Zr/Hf MOFs are based on a similar hexanuclear Zr6O8 or Hf6O8 cluster with various connectivities, and more recent studies have reported the same cluster with Ce. However, this is the first 8-connected (8-c) Th6O8 polyoxo-cluster realized in a Th-MOF structure. Each polyoxo-cluster contains two crystallographically unique thorium atoms. Th1 is 9-coordinated and bound by four linker oxygen atoms, four μ3 bridging oxygen atoms, and one coordinated water molecule. Th2 is also surrounded by 9 oxygen atoms, two of which are from the linkers, two from formic acid, four from μ3 bridging oxygen atoms, and one from coordinated water (). On the other hand, to the best of our knowledge, the tetranuclear thorium polyoxo-cluster in Th-NU-1011, unlike the previously reported tetranuclear thorium cluster in tetrahedral geometry, has not been reported previously in any form of thorium species. However, similar tetranuclear polyoxo-clusters have been observed in a series of rare earth MOFs with csq topology. The overall framework of Th-NU-1011 is charge-balanced with the formula [Th4(μ3-O)2(OH)4(H2O)4(DMF)2(L)2], and it exhibits two crystallographically independent thorium atoms in each polyoxo-cluster (). Th1 and Th2 are bridged by two μ3-O atoms to form a rhombic shaped Th4O2 cluster with planar D 2h symmetry (c). Th1 is coordinated to four oxygen atoms from the linkers, two from the μ3 bridging oxygen atoms, two from DMF, and one from water. Th2 is coordinated to 8 oxygen atoms, four of which are from the linkers, two from the terminal OH, one from μ3 bridging oxygen atoms, and one from coordinated water. The hexanuclear polyoxo-cluster in Th-NU-1008 and the tetranuclear polyoxo-cluster in Th-NU-1011 both serve as 8-c secondary building units which bind to the tetratopic linker to form (4,8)-connected csq MOFs. The pore size of the hexagonal (32 Å in diameter) and triangular channels (15 Å in diameter) in Th-NU-1008 (ca., d) are both larger than those in Th-NU-1011 (10 and 3 Å in diameter for hexagonal and triangular channels respectively, e). Close examination of the crystal structures shows that this difference can be attributed to the linker orientations in these two MOFs. In Th-NU-1008, the short side of the linker aligns with the c axis (f) while, in Th-NU-1011, the long side of the linker aligns with the c axis (g), thus resulting in hexagonal channels with different pore sizes.
elements.clean_text:
Result and Discussion

After adding a suitable amount of water and benzoic acid to the mixture of thorium nitrate and TCPB-Br2 in DMF and heating at 120 °C, pale-yellow rodlike crystals were obtained (). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies of these crystals revealed two different crystal structures, namely, Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011. Both materials crystallized in the hexagonal space group with P6/mmm symmetry for Th-NU-1008 and P6/mcc symmetry for Th-NU-1011 (). However, Th-NU-1008 was observed to display a hexanuclear polyoxo-cluster [Th6(μ3-O)4(OH)4(H2O)6(HCOO)4] while Th-NU-1011 possessed a tetranuclear polyoxo-cluster [Th4(μ3-O)2(OH)4(H2O)4(DMF)2]. The hexanuclear polyoxo-cluster (b) in Th-NU-1008 was similar to those previously reported in discrete hexanuclear thorium polyoxo-clusters and thorium UiO-66. Most reported Zr/Hf MOFs are based on a similar hexanuclear Zr6O8 or Hf6O8 cluster with various connectivities, and more recent studies have reported the same cluster with Ce. However, this is the first 8-connected (8-c) Th6O8 polyoxo-cluster realized in a Th-MOF structure. Each polyoxo-cluster contains two crystallographically unique thorium atoms. Th1 is 9-coordinated and bound by four linker oxygen atoms, four μ3 bridging oxygen atoms, and one coordinated water molecule. Th2 is also surrounded by 9 oxygen atoms, two of which are from the linkers, two from formic acid, four from μ3 bridging oxygen atoms, and one from coordinated water (). On the other hand, to the best of our knowledge, the tetranuclear thorium polyoxo-cluster in Th-NU-1011, unlike the previously reported tetranuclear thorium cluster in tetrahedral geometry, has not been reported previously in any form of thorium species. However, similar tetranuclear polyoxo-clusters have been observed in a series of rare earth MOFs with csq topology. The overall framework of Th-NU-1011 is charge-balanced with the formula [Th4(μ3-O)2(OH)4(H2O)4(DMF)2(L)2], and it exhibits two crystallographically independent thorium atoms in each polyoxo-cluster (). Th1 and Th2 are bridged by two μ3-O atoms to form a rhombic shaped Th4O2 cluster with planar D 2h  symmetry (c). Th1 is coordinated to four oxygen atoms from the linkers, two from the μ3 bridging oxygen atoms, two from DMF, and one from water. Th2 is coordinated to 8 oxygen atoms, four of which are from the linkers, two from the terminal OH, one from μ3 bridging oxygen atoms, and one from coordinated water. The hexanuclear polyoxo-cluster in Th-NU-1008 and the tetranuclear polyoxo-cluster in Th-NU-1011 both serve as 8-c secondary building units which bind to the tetratopic linker to form (4,8)-connected csq MOFs. The pore size of the hexagonal (32 Å in diameter) and triangular channels (15 Å in diameter) in Th-NU-1008 (ca., d) are both larger than those in Th-NU-1011 (10 and 3 Å in diameter for hexagonal and triangular channels respectively, e). Close examination of the crystal structures shows that this difference can be attributed to the linker orientations in these two MOFs. In Th-NU-1008, the short side of the linker aligns with the c axis (f) while, in Th-NU-1011, the long side of the linker aligns with the c axis (g), thus resulting in hexagonal channels with different pore sizes.

elements.content: To test the porosity of Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, the as-synthesized MOFs were activated using supercritical CO2. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns for activated Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 indicate their crystallinity is retained (a,b), and thermogravimetric analyses under N2 demonstrate that Th-NU-1008 is slightly more thermally stable than Th-NU-1011 (Figure S2). We also tested the chemical stability of Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 in air and water/acid/base by PXRD. The results indicate that Th-NU-1008 is stable in air, water, and acid, but not in base, and Th-NU-1011 is only stable in air, but not stable in water, acid, or base (Figure S3). The activated Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 exhibit permanent porosity and display type IV (c) and type I (d) Ar isotherms at 87 K, respectively. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas calculated from the Ar isotherms are approximately 800 and 700 m2 g–1 for Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, respectively. The calculated pore size distribution of Th-NU-1008 shows a small pore of 15 Å and a large pore of 32 Å (e), which are consistent with the pore sizes in the Th-NU-1008 crystal structure. In contrast, there is only one pore size (10 Å) observed for Th-NU-1011 (f).
elements.clean_text: To test the porosity of Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, the as-synthesized MOFs were activated using supercritical CO2. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns for activated Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 indicate their crystallinity is retained (a,b), and thermogravimetric analyses under N2 demonstrate that Th-NU-1008 is slightly more thermally stable than Th-NU-1011 (Figure S2). We also tested the chemical stability of Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 in air and water/acid/base by PXRD. The results indicate that Th-NU-1008 is stable in air, water, and acid, but not in base, and Th-NU-1011 is only stable in air, but not stable in water, acid, or base (Figure S3). The activated Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 exhibit permanent porosity and display type IV (c) and type I (d) Ar isotherms at 87 K, respectively. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas calculated from the Ar isotherms are approximately 800 and 700 m2 g-1 for Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, respectively. The calculated pore size distribution of Th-NU-1008 shows a small pore of 15 Å and a large pore of 32 Å (e), which are consistent with the pore sizes in the Th-NU-1008 crystal structure. In contrast, there is only one pore size (10 Å) observed for Th-NU-1011 (f).

elements.content: (a, b) PXRD patterns, (c, d) Ar isotherms at 87 K, and (e, f) pore size distributions of activated Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a, b) PXRD patterns, (c, d) Ar isotherms at 87 K, and (e, f) pore size distributions of activated Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011.

elements.content: Because controlling the assembly of thorium polyoxo-clusters is crucial for discovering new thorium species, we systematically investigated the solvothermal synthesis conditions for the formation of Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011. The results revealed the occurrence of four distinct phases within a range of water and benzoic acid concentrations ( and Figure S4). In the absence of water and/or benzoic acid, the major phase observed is unknown. Thus, the presence of water and benzoic acid is critical for the formation of the thorium polyoxo-cluster-based MOFs. When the concentration of benzoic acid is as low as 0.3 M and the concentration of water is in the range 2–10 M, Th-NU-1011 is the major phase. However, when the concentration of benzoic acid is higher than 0.3 M, the Th-NU-1008 phase appears. As the starting concentration of water increases, the yield of Th-NU-1008 also increases. When the concentration of water is higher than 6 M, the pure phase of Th-NU-1008 is obtained. The above observations reflect that olation/oxolation hydrolysis reactions can be accelerated by increasing the starting water concentration. Based on previous experimental and theoretical studies of thorium hydrolysis in aqueous solution, the high concentration of benzoic acid lowers the initial pH value and inhibits hydrolysis. Thus, synthesizing thorium polyoxo-cluster-based MOFs requires longer crystallization time since it is difficult for thorium polyoxo-clusters to form in the presence of high concentrations of benzoic acid. As the reaction time becomes longer, the thermodynamically stable Th6O8 cluster is favored instead of the kinetically favored Th4O2 cluster. Therefore, it is more likely to form Th-NU-1008 than Th-NU-1011 when the concentration of benzoic acid is higher. To further test our hypothesis, fresh Th-NU-1011 crystals were added in a solution with benzoic acid under heat; a phase transformation from Th-NU-1011 to Th-NU-1008 was observed after 1 day ().
elements.clean_text: Because controlling the assembly of thorium polyoxo-clusters is crucial for discovering new thorium species, we systematically investigated the solvothermal synthesis conditions for the formation of Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011. The results revealed the occurrence of four distinct phases within a range of water and benzoic acid concentrations ( and Figure S4). In the absence of water and/or benzoic acid, the major phase observed is unknown. Thus, the presence of water and benzoic acid is critical for the formation of the thorium polyoxo-cluster-based MOFs. When the concentration of benzoic acid is as low as 0.3 M and the concentration of water is in the range 2-10 M, Th-NU-1011 is the major phase. However, when the concentration of benzoic acid is higher than 0.3 M, the Th-NU-1008 phase appears. As the starting concentration of water increases, the yield of Th-NU-1008 also increases. When the concentration of water is higher than 6 M, the pure phase of Th-NU-1008 is obtained. The above observations reflect that olation/oxolation hydrolysis reactions can be accelerated by increasing the starting water concentration. Based on previous experimental and theoretical studies of thorium hydrolysis in aqueous solution, the high concentration of benzoic acid lowers the initial pH value and inhibits hydrolysis. Thus, synthesizing thorium polyoxo-cluster-based MOFs requires longer crystallization time since it is difficult for thorium polyoxo-clusters to form in the presence of high concentrations of benzoic acid. As the reaction time becomes longer, the thermodynamically stable Th6O8 cluster is favored instead of the kinetically favored Th4O2 cluster. Therefore, it is more likely to form Th-NU-1008 than Th-NU-1011 when the concentration of benzoic acid is higher. To further test our hypothesis, fresh Th-NU-1011 crystals were added in a solution with benzoic acid under heat; a phase transformation from Th-NU-1011 to Th-NU-1008 was observed after 1 day ().

elements.content: Phase map based on the starting concentration of H2O and benzoic acid in solvothermal conditions, showing the domains of occurrence of the four phases: Th-NU-1008 (red ■), Th-NU-1011 (blue ●), mixture phase (black ◆), and unknown phase (pink ★).

elements.content: In conclusion, two thorium polyoxo-cluster-based metal–organic frameworks with (4,8)-connected csq topology, Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 (the tetranuclear cluster in Th-NU-1011 is unprecedented among all reported thorium species), were synthesized under solvothermal reaction conditions with water and benzoic acid added as two important modulators. Additionally, the different orientations of organic linkers in the crystal structures lead to different pore sizes in Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011. Importantly, we developed a synthetic method to control the formation of targeted thorium polyoxo-clusters in Th-MOFs by tuning the concentration of modulators. We hope that this work will open a new avenue to construct unexplored Th-MOF materials with targeted polyoxo-cluster structures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, two thorium polyoxo-cluster-based metal-organic frameworks with (4,8)-connected csq topology, Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 (the tetranuclear cluster in Th-NU-1011 is unprecedented among all reported thorium species), were synthesized under solvothermal reaction conditions with water and benzoic acid added as two important modulators. Additionally, the different orientations of organic linkers in the crystal structures lead to different pore sizes in Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011. Importantly, we developed a synthetic method to control the formation of targeted thorium polyoxo-clusters in Th-MOFs by tuning the concentration of modulators. We hope that this work will open a new avenue to construct unexplored Th-MOF materials with targeted polyoxo-cluster structures.

elements.content:
Caution! Thorium nitrate (Th­(NO 3 ) 4 ·5H 2 O) is a radioactive and chemically toxic reactant. Thus, suitable care, precautions, and protection for handling such substances have been followed.

Thorium nitrate (Th­(NO3)4·5H2O) (≥98%, International Bio-Analytical Industries, Inc., radiation clearance tested), benzoic acid (99%, Sigma-Aldrich), N,N-dimethylformamide (≥99.8%, certified ACS, Fisher Scientific), and anhydrous ethanol (95.27%, histological grade, Fisher Scientific) were purchased from the supplier and used without further purification. The 1,4-Dibromo-2,3,5,6-tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl) benzene was synthesized following the reported procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Methods

Materials

 Caution! Thorium nitrate (Th(NO  3  )  4  ⋅5H  2  O) is a radioactive and chemically toxic reactant. Thus, suitable care, precautions, and protection for handling such substances have been followed.

Thorium nitrate (Th(NO3)4⋅5H2O) (≥98%, International Bio-Analytical Industries, Inc., radiation clearance tested), benzoic acid (99%, Sigma-Aldrich), N,N-dimethylformamide (≥99.8%, certified ACS, Fisher Scientific), and anhydrous ethanol (95.27%, histological grade, Fisher Scientific) were purchased from the supplier and used without further purification. The 1,4-Dibromo-2,3,5,6-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl) benzene was synthesized following the reported procedures.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction was measured at room temperature on a STOE-STADI MP powder diffractometer equipped with an asymmetric curved germanium monochromator (Cu Kα1 radiation, λ = 1.540 56 Å) and a one-dimensional silicon strip detector (MYTHEN2 1K from DECTRIS). The line focused Cu X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Ar sorption isotherm measurements were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 instrument (Micromeritics, Norcross, GA) at 87 K. The data points between 0.03 and 0.14 P/P 0 were chosen for the BET surface area calculation to minimize the error for consistency criteria (R 2 = 0.999). Between 30 and 50 mg of material was used for each measurement.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Methods and Measurements

Powder X-ray diffraction was measured at room temperature on a STOE-STADI MP powder diffractometer equipped with an asymmetric curved germanium monochromator (Cu Kα1 radiation, λ = 1.54056 Å) and a one-dimensional silicon strip detector (MYTHEN2 1K from DECTRIS). The line focused Cu X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Ar sorption isotherm measurements were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 instrument (Micromeritics, Norcross, GA) at 87 K. The data points between 0.03 and 0.14 P/P 0 were chosen for the BET surface area calculation to minimize the error for consistency criteria (R 2 = 0.999). Between 30 and 50 mg of material was used for each measurement.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a TGA/DCS 1 system (Mettler-Toledo AG, Schwerzenbach, Switzerland), which runs on a PC with STARe software. Samples were heated from 25 to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min–1 under flowing N2.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a TGA/DCS 1 system (Mettler-Toledo AG, Schwerzenbach, Switzerland), which runs on a PC with STARe software. Samples were heated from 25 to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min-1 under flowing N2.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray structure analyses were carried out using a Bruker Kappa APEX II CCD detector equipped with a Cu Kα (λ = 1.541 78 Å) I μS microsource with MX optics. The single crystals were mounted on MicroMesh (MiTeGen) with paratone oil. The structures were determined by direct methods (SHELXT 2014/5) and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinement (SHELXL-2017/1) using the Yadokari-XG56 or Olex257 software packages. The disordered noncoordinated solvents were removed using the PLATON SQUEEZE program. The refinement results are summarized in Table S1. Crystallographic data for the Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 crystal structures in CIF format have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC) under deposition numbers CCDC-1875458 and CCDC-1882912. The data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, U.K.).
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

Single-crystal X-ray structure analyses were carried out using a Bruker Kappa APEX II CCD detector equipped with a Cu Kα (λ = 1.54178 Å) I μS microsource with MX optics. The single crystals were mounted on MicroMesh (MiTeGen) with paratone oil. The structures were determined by direct methods (SHELXT 2014/5) and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinement (SHELXL-2017/1) using the Yadokari-XG56 or Olex257 software packages. The disordered noncoordinated solvents were removed using the PLATON SQUEEZE program. The refinement results are summarized in Table S1. Crystallographic data for the Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 crystal structures in CIF format have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC) under deposition numbers CCDC-1875458 and CCDC-1882912. The data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, U.K.).

elements.content: A 1000 mg portion (1.75 mmol) of Th­(NO3)4·5H2O was dissolved in 20 mL of DMF to form stock solution A. A 100 mg portion (0.14 mmol) of TCPB-Br2 was dissolved in 10 mL of DMF to form stock solution B. A 5 g portion (41 mmol) of benzoic acid was dissolved in 10 mL of DMF to form stock solution C.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Th-MOFs

A 1000 mg portion (1.75 mmol) of Th(NO3)4⋅5H2O was dissolved in 20 mL of DMF to form stock solution A. A 100 mg portion (0.14 mmol) of TCPB-Br2 was dissolved in 10 mL of DMF to form stock solution B. A 5 g portion (41 mmol) of benzoic acid was dissolved in 10 mL of DMF to form stock solution C.

elements.content: In the following order, 400 μL of solution A, 400 μL of solution B, 100 μL of H2O, and 400 μL of solution C were added to a 1.5 dram vial, resulting in a clear solution (pH = 3.7). The 1.5 dram vial was placed into an oven at 120 °C for 1 day, during which time white, rodlike crystals formed (ca. 72% in yield). After cooling down to room temperature, the crystal solid was collected and further washed with DMF and ethanol three times, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Single Crystal of Th-NU-1008

The 1.5 dram vial was placed into an oven at 120 °C for 1 day, during which time white, rodlike crystals formed (ca. 85% in yield). After cooling down to room temperature, the crystal solid was collected and further washed with DMF and ethanol three times, respectively.

The 1.5 dram vial was placed into an oven at 120 °C for 1 day. elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Mixture Phase of Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 

In the following order, 400 μL of solution A, 400 μL of solution B, 60 μL of H2O, and 200 μL of solution C were added to a 1.5 dram vial resulting in a clear solution (pH = 4.6). The 1.5 dram vial was placed into an oven at 120 °C for 1 day. After cooling down to room temperature, the crystal solid was collected and further washed with DMF and ethanol three times, respectively.

elements.content: Freshly made 10 mg Th-NU-1011 single crystals were soaked in 2 mL of solution C in a 1.5 dram vial. The 1.5 dram vial was placed into an oven at 120 °C for 1 day. After cooling down to room temperature, the crystal solid was collected and further washed with DMF and ethanol three times, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Phase Transformation from Th-NU-1011 to Th-NU-1008 

Freshly made 10 mg Th-NU-1011 single crystals were soaked in 2 mL of solution C in a 1.5 dram vial. The 1.5 dram vial was placed into an oven at 120 °C for 1 day. After cooling down to room temperature, the crystal solid was collected and further washed with DMF and ethanol three times, respectively.

elements.content: The MOF crystals were soaked in fresh ethanol for 2 days, and then activated with supercritical carbon dioxide (sc-CO2) using a Tousimis Samdri PVT-3D critical point dryer at a bleed rate of 1.0 cc min–1.
elements.clean_text:
Activation of MOFs

The MOF crystals were soaked in fresh ethanol for 2 days, and then activated with supercritical carbon dioxide (sc-CO2) using a Tousimis Samdri PVT-3D critical point dryer at a bleed rate of 1.0 cc min-1.

elements.content: A 10 mg portion of activated Th-NU-1008 or Th-NU-1011 was exposed to air and soaked in neutral water solution (pH = 7), acid solution (pH = 2), and base solution (pH = 12) for 24 h. The PXRD patterns were measured after each treatment.
elements.clean_text:
Stability Test of MOFs

A 10 mg portion of activated Th-NU-1008 or Th-NU-1011 was exposed to air and soaked in neutral water solution (pH = 7), acid solution (pH = 2), and base solution (pH = 12) for 24 h. The PXRD patterns were measured after each treatment.

cln_elements.content:
Control over the assembly of thorium-based polyoxo-clusters remains a great challenge because of their quick olation and oxolation reactions. Here, we report the synthesis and isolation of two pure phase thorium polyoxo-cluster-based metal–organic frameworks (Th-MOFs), Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011. Crystal structures of these Th-MOFs reveal two distinct 8-connected polyoxo-clusters: a hexanuclear cluster [Th6(μ3-O)4(OH)4(H2O)6(HCOO)4] was observed in Th-NU-1008 and a tetranuclear cluster [Th4(μ3-O)2(OH)4(DMF)2(H2O)4] in Th-NU-1011 which has never been reported before among thorium species. In both Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, the tetratopic linker, 1,4-dibromo-2,3,5,6-tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl) benzene, joins the clusters together, forming two three-periodic networks, each with csq topology. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas calculated from the Ar isotherms are approximately 800 and 700 m2 g–1 for Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, respectively. Because the linkers are oriented orthogonal to each other in the two respective MOFs, a 32 Å hexagonal channel is observed in Th-NU-1008 while a 15 Å channel is observed in Th-NU-1011. This work opens a new avenue to construct unexplored Th-MOF materials with targeted polyoxo-cluster structures.

To test the porosity of Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, the as-synthesized MOFs were activated using supercritical CO2. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns for activated Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 indicate their crystallinity is retained (a,b), and thermogravimetric analyses under N2 demonstrate that Th-NU-1008 is slightly more thermally stable than Th-NU-1011 (Figure S2). We also tested the chemical stability of Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 in air and water/acid/base by PXRD. The results indicate that Th-NU-1008 is stable in air, water, and acid, but not in base, and Th-NU-1011 is only stable in air, but not stable in water, acid, or base (Figure S3). The activated Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 exhibit permanent porosity and display type IV (c) and type I (d) Ar isotherms at 87 K, respectively. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas calculated from the Ar isotherms are approximately 800 and 700 m2 g–1 for Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, respectively. The calculated pore size distribution of Th-NU-1008 shows a small pore of 15 Å and a large pore of 32 Å (e), which are consistent with the pore sizes in the Th-NU-1008 crystal structure. In contrast, there is only one pore size (10 Å) observed for Th-NU-1011 (f).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Control over the assembly of thorium-based polyoxo-clusters remains a great challenge because of their quick olation and oxolation reactions. Here, we report the synthesis and isolation of two pure phase thorium polyoxo-cluster-based metal-organic frameworks (Th-MOFs), Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011. Crystal structures of these Th-MOFs reveal two distinct 8-connected polyoxo-clusters: a hexanuclear cluster [Th6(μ3-O)4(OH)4(H2O)6(HCOO)4] was observed in Th-NU-1008 and a tetranuclear cluster [Th4(μ3-O)2(OH)4(DMF)2(H2O)4] in Th-NU-1011 which  has never been reported before among thorium species. In both Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, the tetratopic linker, 1,4-dibromo-2,3,5,6-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl) benzene, joins the clusters together, forming two three-periodic networks, each with csq topology. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas calculated from the Ar isotherms are approximately 800 and 700 m2 g-1 for Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, respectively. Because the linkers are oriented orthogonal to each other in the two respective MOFs, a 32 Å hexagonal channel is observed in Th-NU-1008 while a 15 Å channel is observed in Th-NU-1011. This work opens a new avenue to construct unexplored Th-MOF materials with targeted polyoxo-cluster structures.

To test the porosity of Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, the as-synthesized MOFs were activated using supercritical CO2. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns for activated Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 indicate their crystallinity is retained (a,b), and thermogravimetric analyses under N2 demonstrate that Th-NU-1008 is slightly more thermally stable than Th-NU-1011 (Figure S2). We also tested the chemical stability of Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 in air and water/acid/base by PXRD. The results indicate that Th-NU-1008 is stable in air, water, and acid, but not in base, and Th-NU-1011 is only stable in air, but not stable in water, acid, or base (Figure S3). The activated Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011 exhibit permanent porosity and display type IV (c) and type I (d) Ar isotherms at 87 K, respectively. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas calculated from the Ar isotherms are approximately 800 and 700 m2 g-1 for Th-NU-1008 and Th-NU-1011, respectively. The calculated pore size distribution of Th-NU-1008 shows a small pore of 15 Å and a large pore of 32 Å (e), which are consistent with the pore sizes in the Th-NU-1008 crystal structure. In contrast, there is only one pore size (10 Å) observed for Th-NU-1011 (f).

cln_elements.content: (a) Dimensions of TCPB-Br2 linker. (b) Hexanuclear polyoxo-cluster in Th-NU-1008. (c) Tetranuclear polyoxo-cluster in Th-NU-1011 with the rhombic shape highlighted in purple. Packing diagram of (d) Th-NU-1008 and (e) Th-NU-1011 along the c axis showing hexagonal and triangular channels. Side view of linker orientations (marked in black dashed rectangles) in (f) Th-NU-1008 and (g) Th-NU-1011 along a axis. Th is represented in cyan, O in red, C in gray, and N in blue.

metadata.title:
Synthetic Control of Thorium Polyoxo-Clusters in Metal–Organic
Frameworks toward New Thorium-Based Materials
